Posts.Content: Sep 3, 2011 09:49PM NancyJill wrote: Joan 811, I think we have similar situations. I had lumpectomy and SNB on 8/26. I had arrived at the hospital at 7:30 for a 12:30 surgery that wasn't really happening until 1:30. I agree, waiting was a drag, especially with a headache. I had to ask for Tylenol, but it was still raging during wire guide placement and mammo, and through dye injection (ouch, ouch, ouch!) and pictures of tht. Finally I got some drugs from the nurse anesthetist! I was amazed at how well I felt on day 1 at home. 8 days later I have more fluid in the "empty" space than last week. My bruises are smaller and fading. My incisions are sensitive, though. I had no need for pain meds after the second night home. I'm warm and a bit swollen, but not feverish. Luckily, no problems with arms, and the surgeon took out 12 nodes. The best thing? All nodes were negative for cancer. Good luck with your pathology report!
Posts.Title: August 2011 Surgery Group blondelawyer Joan811

Posts.Content: Sep 5, 2011 09:51AM NancyJill wrote: cbecchetti:  I am so sorry you have to have either another re-excision or MX or BMX. I thought my 6 cm excision was a lot--you are right there with me. I haven't shrunken yet to how my size will be--still swollen with fluid from lumpectomy. I am lucky my doctor got to within 1.8 mm on the closest side to my DCIS, 1 cm on closest side to my IDC tumor. Why couldn't you do the MRI? It will provide more information about the other side that may help with your surgical decisions.
Posts.Title: August 2011 Surgery Group blondelawyer Joan811

Posts.Content: Sep 20, 2011 09:11AM - edited Sep 21, 2011 02:15PM by NancyJill It is strange; so much waiting, then 5 appointments (MO, MUGA heart test, chemo. ed. with nurse, wig and port) all in one week! Hurry up and wait....for myself, I'm deciding to reduce my commitments. Sigh.....
Posts.Title: August 2011 Surgery Group blondelawyer Joan811

Posts.Content: Sep 6, 2011 10:15AM NancyJill wrote: rockym and dawmson, I had lump/SNB Aug. 26. 12 nodes removed, but no numbness. Just discomfort from seroma (fluid) and sensitivity of incisions due to that swelling, which didn't really kick in for a week. I'm allowed ibuprofen/ice packs and was told to take it easy to reduce fluid build-up when I called this weekend (holiday or no!). No more treadmill for a while.
Posts.Title: August 2011 Surgery Group blondelawyer Joan811

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2011 04:08PM NancyJill wrote: Joan811, got my pathology results on 8/31. All nodes negative. 1 cm IDC, 3.5 cm of DCIS. Margins clear around tumor (1 cm), "close" 1.8 mm around DCIS. Surgeon thinks they are clear enough. Will meet oncologist on Friday. I am expecting radiation. Also looking forward to corroboration that 1.8 mm is enough of a margin with DCIS, along with radiation. When do you get your results?
Posts.Title: August 2011 Surgery Group blondelawyer Joan811

Posts.Content: Sep 19, 2011 11:06AM - edited Sep 19, 2011 11:06AM by NancyJill Hello, Lump/SNB sisters--three weeks post-lumpectomy I am much less swollen with great mobility. No real pain-just some tenderness right on the stitches and at the lump site. Some nipple sensitivity where I had the dye injected for the SNB--would like that to go away--expecting it will. It is hard for me to remember to take it easy on my affected arm since it feels so normal. I don't want LE, but I also like being able to do normal things. It's hard to know where to draw the line, exactly. Today I am getting my chemo plan since I finally found out I am really a HER2+. A let-down, for sure, but everyone says chemo/Herceptin are so doable. So I will do it! Time to think about wigs, I guess....

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2011 09:28PM - edited Sep 27, 2011 09:29PM by NancyJill My Lump/SNB procedure seems to have been quite successful, but little pains feel better with a little masage. Had port placed yesterday and first Herceptin today. Needed a nap, that's all. Lucky to have no cording or LE so far. What I have done is gain weight from stress-related overeating. Sigh.... I'm going to have to change my bad habits. I think I need to see a dietician in order to get psyched for reducing my risk of recurrence! BlondeLawyer: I'm so glad that the procedure helped so much! You deserve to be able to move on!
Posts.Title: August 2011 Surgery Group blondelawyer Joan811

Posts.Content: Sep 27, 2011 09:37PM NancyJill wrote: Susanella, Sorry you have to join us. I, too, had no family with this. Yes, a shock! It is okay to slow down a little. You will learn what things mean soon enough. MRIs do sometimes change the treatment plan, and mine showed a spot they then had to biopsy in the other breast. However, if it had been a tiny tumor I would have wanted to know. It might have changed my treatment decisions. We are going to be all right! You'll know a lot more after the pathology from the biopsy comes back. Surgery was where my BS decided how many nodes needed to be checked and the pathology from surgery gives the final result on nodes.

Posts.Content: Nov 20, 2018 07:29AM - edited Nov 20, 2018 07:30AM by NancyJill Joan, Dixie and all, I haven't checked in for a long time. I'm sorry to hear about your continued health challenges but am finding it good that there is some joy, also. Yes, I'm almost 7 years cancer-free. I have been launching my 3 kids into adulthood: a first job, college, high school. I notice no lingering effects from BC except a PT told me Tamoxifen is partly to blame for my lack of muscle tone in my therapy for stress incontinence when I cough or jog. I'm doing Kegels and getting stronger in my core. I'm thinking of getting my counselor license and focusing on cancer patients. I have 2 classes to take before I can take a certifying test. I used to be a therapist in Michigan. Now I'm in Illinois. I'm thinking about a training I went to: Meaning Centered Psychotherapy. There are many ways to find joy: family, work, art, legacies. I'm inspired by all of you warriors! Thank you and happy holidays! NancyJil

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2012 08:38PM NancyJill wrote: Hi, ladies, I had my 6-month-out MRI and it was good! I only have targeted boosts left for Rads--2 weeks and I'll be done. I'm on Tamoxifen now and have no problems with it. I am getting hair back and have started to go to the doctor and treatments without a wig. It is so short--about 3/4 inch. Grateful for my lumpectomy but eager to be done with Rads. Will continue with Herceptin until October, every 3 weeks. What a lot of treatment for stage 1. However, I was "lucky", and couldn't tolerate the Taxotere/Cytoxan past one cycle (due to allergic reaction), so got Navelbine for the last 9 weeks of chemo. It wasn't so bad.  Eema, sorry about this complication you have to deal with!  I've lost 5 of the 10 pounds I gained and am looking forward to spring exercise.
Posts.Title: August 2011 Surgery Group blondelawyer Joan811

Posts.Content: Apr 7, 2016 08:27AM NancyJill wrote: Hello to all in August 2011 Surgery Group! I am sorry some of us are gone or are experiencing recurrences. I remain NED. I have no side effects to Tamoxifen. One year left to go on that and it's only 4 months until the 5 years post surgery mark. This year I experienced cording in my arm. I've had it twice in the last couple of years, and I just massage it. I haven't needed to get physical therapy. I have some throbbing feelings at my surgical site. My last mammo was clear, but there is a lump of what my onc says is scar tissue. I'm thinking about going to my surgeon to see what she thinks. I also had my blood drawn to see if I'm pre- or post-menopausal. I don't think my doc will switch me from Tamoxifen to an aromatase inhibitor at this late date, but she always asks. Warm wishes to all.
Posts.Title: August 2011 Surgery Group blondelawyer Joan811

Posts.Content: Oct 8, 2011 05:08PM NancyJill wrote: Day 3 and 4: Intestinal cramps. MO on call said it is from nerve damage, slowing down my bowel, due to the chemo. She advised Colace or Miralax because they help provide bulk rather than forcing the colon into doing something it's not ready to do. Heating pad or warm water bottle. I'm to call if I get nausea or very distended.  I had hoped no nausea would mean no stomach issues. Wrong!

Posts.Content: Feb 16, 2012 07:01AM NancyJill wrote: I am done with chemo--still have Herceptin so my port stays. Started rads and don't like it. Then I will see her and hopefully not have to go back unless future scans show an abnormality or until I'm ready to get the port out after a year on Herceptin. I am sleeping a lot, but have not caught any viruses while my blood counts have been low. I have about half an inch to 3/4 inch of hair--needs coloring and shaping before going without the wig. My first and last hair-affecting chemo was in October-patience is needed.

Posts.Title: Greetings From the Other Side (post op) Michele_T NancyJill

Posts.Content: Mar 16, 2012 09:44AM - edited Mar 16, 2012 09:47AM by NancyJill Hi, all, I was on Navelbine for 9 weeks (with a few breaks in between) because my first round of chemo was T/C and I was allergic to the Taxotere: got hives all over my hands, itchy mouth, in addition to the chemo head, mouth sores, constipation, hair loss, etc. Yes, sometimes I had to take a week off because my blood counts went so low. I did not get Neupogen with Navelbine as I did with Taxotere. Other than napping a lot, I didn't have side effects I noticed. I did not get sick during that time. My hair fell out in October from Taxotere and then started growing back with Navelbine. I just started going with no wig yesterday!! I think this is a common drug for late stage or mets. There is little data on using it with Stage 1, HER2 + like me. Anyone else early stage with Navelbine??
Posts.Title: Need Info on Navelbine LuAnnH jcb51

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2011 01:41AM - edited Aug 22, 2011 11:22PM by NancyJill At first I told my sisters/spouse only. Then I told some friends about having tests. I waited to tell my elderly parents and kids because I didn't want them to worry too much when there were more questions than answers. But when the diagnosis was bc I told them along with a lot of other family and several friends. I am glad since I am receiving support and they feel glad that they can help/listen/support, each in their own way. It's helping. However, there are some people I don't want to talk with about this at all or very much, and I've decided that's just fine!
Posts.Title: How did you handle telling family when diagnosed? watchfuleye funsizejen

Posts.Content: NancyJill wrote: I had a rather large lumpectomy-6 cm-really considered partial mastectomy. I saw my surgeon today and she said the area is filled with fluid. However, the area is now also warmer to the touch than the surrounding tissue. Does this mean I am developing an infection? Does the area filled with fluid feel warmer for any other possible reason? Dx 8/15/2011, IDC, Right, 1cm, Stage IA, Grade 2, 0/11 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ (FISH) Targeted Therapy 9/27/2011 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Chemotherapy 10/10/2011 Cytoxan (cyclophosphamide), Navelbine (vinorelbine), Taxotere (docetaxel) Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Warm area after lumpectomy? NancyJill NancyJill

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2011 07:00PM NancyJill wrote: I caved and called the surgeon's answering service. The doctor on call said I have a seroma, warm is okay, slightly pink and swollen is okay. I should be concerned about infection if there is redness or fever. Ice packs, Tylenol or ibuprofen are okay. And I should take it easier because too much activity causes more fluid leaking into the cavity. Interesting. So I wrote thank-you notes for flowers and meals instead of washing pots and pans!
Posts.Title: Warm area after lumpectomy? NancyJill NancyJill

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2011 12:22AM NancyJill wrote: This has been helpful, thanks. I learned at my BS appointment that the IDC was 1 cm, but the adjacent DCIS was 3.5 cm. The excised tissue was about 6 cm. So it makes sense to me that healing is going on! I have no fever or redness, but feel a bit more tender than a week ago, when I had surgery. My gut instinct is that I'm healing, I think.... I had worse fever and redness from mastitis when I was breastfeeding! So I will watch it and call the surgeon if I don't feel well. In the meantime, I'm comfortably warm .
Posts.Title: Warm area after lumpectomy? NancyJill NancyJill
